sn55.22:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.
sn55.22:1.3: Then Mahānāma the Sakyan went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:
sn55.22:1.4: “Sir, this Kapilavatthu is successful and prosperous and full of people, with cramped cul-de-sacs.
sn55.22:1.5: In the late afternoon, after paying homage to the Buddha or an esteemed mendicant, I enter Kapilavatthu.
sn55.22:1.11: At that time I lose mindfulness regarding the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha.
sn55.22:1.13: ‘If I were to die at this time, where would I be reborn in my next life?’”
sn55.22:2.1: “Do not fear, Mahānāma, do not fear!
sn55.22:2.2: Your death will not be a bad one; your passing will not be a bad one.
sn55.22:2.3: A noble disciple who has four things slants, slopes, and inclines towards extinguishment.
sn55.22:2.5: It’s when a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Buddha …
sn55.22:2.9: And they have the ethical conduct loved by the noble ones … leading to immersion.
sn55.22:3.1: Suppose there was a tree that slants, slopes, and inclines to the east. If it was cut off at the root where would it fall?”
sn55.22:3.2: “Sir, it would fall in the direction that it slants, slopes, and inclines.”
sn55.22:3.3: “In the same way, a noble disciple who has four things slants, slopes, and inclines towards extinguishment.”
